required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy of Mydriatic Drops in Premature Infants
clinical_study.official_title: Efficiency and Safety of Phenylephrine and Tropicamide Used in Premature Retinopathy

brief_summary.textblock: Because of the neonatologists reported that some infants had suffered from vomiting, bradycardia, hypotonia, and aspiration risk about 30-60 minutes after the fundus examination in the intensive care unit. The investigators observed the pupil dilation effects and side effects of tipple instillation of phenylephrine 2.5% plus tropicamide 0.5% ophthalmic drop combination which the investigators routinely used in ROP examination.

detailed_description.textblock:
Purpose: To determine effect and vital change after topical application of phenylephrine 2.5% and tropicamide 0.5% three times for retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) examination in preterm infants.
Methods: Pupillary diameter, blood pressure, pulse rate, and oxygen saturation were monitored before, and after up to 24 hours 60 ROP screening examinations.

primary_outcome.description: will be measured with a ruler after 60 minutes instillation of mydriatic

intervention.intervention_name: Drug used in the examination of premature infants.
intervention.description: to investigate side effects of eye drops used

study_pop.textblock: tertiary health center in the west Black Sea region

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Infants who were first ROP examinations
- infants born before 32 weeks.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Developmental ocular and/or systemic anomalies.
- Drug use that can affect vital values
- Unstable general condition
- Food intolerance
- Recurrent vomiting.
